narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Econ of social catastrophes and basic math associated w it

I learned about different types of catastrophes and the socioeconomic effects associated with them. Catastrophes we studied included population catastrophes (overpopulation and/or resource depletion), climate change, pandemics, and war. One of the most interesting concepts we learned about was the Integrate Assessment Model of Climate Change and valuing the social cost of carbon.

I developed a wide breadth of knowledge on an array of social catastrophes, from nuclear war and pandemics to climate change. I learned more about the economic theory behind these catastrophes, why and when they occurred, and how to effectively manage and prevent them.
Great
I learned about a number of social catastrophes: pandemics, climate change, economic, war, nuclear, population, etc. I wrote an economic paper of ~20 pages in length and conducted my own research.

The course provided me with a survey of different types of catastrophes as well as an overview of their effects and the methods for modeling them. The material had an especially strong focus on climate change economics, with other parts addressing areas including pandemics, war, and population catastrophes.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strength was interesting relevant material. Weaknesses was that nordhaus seemed to plan it as he went along, failing to provide an overview of topics or assignments far in advance

Strengths: Interesting and relevant lecture topics

Weaknesses: Not a very engaging class, minimal feedback, unstructured schedules.

I thought the course's material was well organized and the topics covered felt relevant and thoroughly examined. I also thought the assignments did a good job of expanding on or applying the course material in a challenging but manageable way. As for weaknesses, I would have liked to cover a wider range of catastrophes (asteroids, AI, etc.) in more depth that were only briefly mentioned at the start of the course. I was already somewhat familiar with a few of the catastrophe categories we thoroughly examined, so getting more detail on those other catastrophes would have been even more fascinating.
All good

Strengths: I enjoyed writing the final paper. I also learned a lot about the economics of climate change that I didn't know already. 

Weaknesses: lack of clarity in the course. Probably because it is the first time the course is being taught. Our syllabus had little mention of exams and Professor Nordhaus appeared to be making the course as he went along (we would sometimes learn about an exam only a week before). This was difficult because our expectations felt like they were constantly changing and there were 3 instances where we were expected to meet outside of class hours. In the end we had regular readings, problem sets, 2 midterm exams, 1 final exam, and a 20 paged research paper. Professor Nordhaus wasn't very accessible to reach.

The major strength of this course is that you get to take a class with a truly brilliant leader in the field of climate change economics: Professor Nordhaus. He is a great lecturer, teacher, and person. That being said, students only receive a fraction of the benefits that they could from him due to his lack of engagement with or attention to the course. He renders himself almost completely inaccessible to students throughout the semester -- for course-related or non course-related questions or issues. Although the course was technically a seminar, it really functioned more as a lecture (at best) in terms of access to the professor. As a whole, the course was an absolute mess, and the disorganization was its biggest weakness. The content disproportionately oriented around climate change economics and climate-related catastrophes. Most other types of catastrophes seemed as though they were added into the curriculum rather haphazardly and the topics were only covered at a surface level. The actual logistics of the class were in even greater disarray. Tests, assignments, quizzes, and other course elements were poorly managed, with insufficient communication and information -- an issue which was only exacerbated by the TF's lack of knowledge of the course material. These weaknesses hamstrung the class and diminished Professor Nordhaus's ability to have a meaningful impact as a teacher. All of this being said, I think much of this problem could be addressed by having either an assistant or another professor (co-teaching) associated with the course (and a better TF). Professor Nordhaus really is a great teacher and an even better person, but the disorganized and haphazard nature of the course dominated these qualities and made it impossible for them to shine.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The lectures were good, breakout rooms were a good effort but didn't really work as the topics for discussion usually were not what people would have wanted to discuss

All lectures were recorded (in theory), which really helped me review material I had missed the first time or re-examine a student presentation that was particularly fascinating. However, several lectures weren't recorded because of technical difficulties, which is an area that could be improved. Additionally, I really enjoyed the take-home format of the first exam, particularly given the virtual format and ongoing pandemic. I would have liked for the second and final exam to also be take-home, as for me it relieves stress without forfeiting any of the critical thinking elements of the exam.
Was good
I would appreciate it if there were weekly professor office hours.

Zoom lectures worked well and Professor Nordhaus always encouraged our feedback on class structure. That being said, I think that there were issues associated with using the Canvas Quizzes feature for exams that went unaddressed. Namely, the time limits for the tests did not account for the additional time it took to use the formula editor in Canvas Quizzes.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes but be prepared for poor organization
No. The class has a lot of potential with its interesting subject matter, but it was way too unstructured.
Great

If you are interested in taking a seminar with Professor Nordhaus, consider taking the class. I didn't enjoy the course, but I did learn a little on climate change and I enjoyed writing the final paper.

In its current form, no. With a bit of reorganization and a co-professor or assistant, possibly yes. While Professor Nordhaus is a brilliant leader in his field, a great teacher, and a wonderful person, his lack of engagement with and attention to the course and its students stifle these positive qualities. Although the lectures and material are exciting, they are covered in very little depth and do not necessarily provide you with the tools to analyze related problems in a substantive way. A course with a professor as renowned as Professor Nordhaus is difficult to pass up, but the disorganized nature of the course hinders its positive elements so significantly that you may very well leave the class having learned little to nothing.
